Hi my name is Jennifer Dolsen and I'm presenting upsampling range data in dynamic environments, joint work with John Glenn Beck, Christian.
Edmonton Sebastian Thrun.
Suppose you want to leverage depth information in a scene to perform image segmentation.
For example, a first step in many common computer vision algorithms.
Given an optical camera and a source of sparse depth information, we can recover accurate high resolution color depth images at every camera frame.
For outdoor dynamic scenes in real time.

As shown by the images on the slide, the problem with dynamic scenes is that if you have a source of depth data and a source of image data, and they're not recorded simultaneously, then you have to find correspondences for depth values and image pixels.
Also, most sources of depth information or sparse compared to the resolution of the camera.
This problem is seen in the case of a scanning laser range Finder, which is the most accurate method for recovering depth in outdoor long range measurements.

So if you want to use our method, you can use our method with depth data at as little as 2.5% of all camera pixels and we can return a confidence value at each pixel automatically that can reliably predict the accuracy of our resulting depth map.
We do this by leveraging existing work in accelerated high dimensional filtering, projecting our data into a high dimensional space to interpolate in both space and time.
If you want to find out more about this work, please visit our poster or our project website.
Thank you.

So our paper is about estimation shape, estimation of mirrors and so if you look at the range of object reflectance is from lamberson at one and mirror reflectance at the other.

We have a remarkably well good understanding of how to estimate the shape of lamberson objects and so there are a lot of practical algorithms and practical methods that help us estimate the shape of lamberson objects.
However, this is not true for about mirror objects and part of the reason is because it's an extremely hard problem.

When we look at the shape when you look at an image of a mirror, what we're looking at is a distortion of the scene surrounding the mirror and not, and there are hardly any geometric properties of the mirror that gets reflected onto the image that we see.
And so essentially the mirror has no appearance of its own, and all you're seeing is distortion of the surrounding scene.

Unless we know the surrounding scene extremely well, it's very hard to characterize the shape of the mirror directly from a single image, so we addressed this particular problem we had recently proposed an algorithm for estimating the shape of a mirror along the lines of recent work on shape from specular flow.
We provide a practical a very simple algorithm that overcomes some of the main challenges in existing theory and something that works really well with.

Hi, my name is Bianca Lou and I'm from Stanford University.
So an image is the projection.
3 dimensional scene onto 2 dimensional plane.
Recovering the 3D geometry of the original scene is crucial to dealing with issues such as occlusion and relative object scale.
Now human vision is capable of discerning 3D structure with only a single.
I intuitively were able to do this because we have a semantic understanding of the scene.
For example, we know what the structure of the floor or building is without even having to look at it.
Furthermore, the appearance of an object and its relationship to the object depth is heavily dependent on the type of the object.
For example, a nearby tree would look very detailed, intricate with many leaves, whereas a nearby building might look relatively smooth and featureless.
Building on top of this intuition, we present a depth estimation model that independently models the depth of different semantic classes.
Our model also incorporates constraints that capture the geometry of image formation.
Unlike previous work, we do not rely on.
High quality human labeled semantic information at Test time, and Furthermore we use similar image features.
Nonetheless, by leveraging the power of semantic inference, we were able to achieve state of the art results on 2 standard metrics for 3D depth estimation.
Thank you.
